HEADER.tool: A tool of the ecosystem from

DROPDOWN.text: Sites and tools to support accessibility and usability, to ensure promotion good practices and improve the experience of using digital services.

accessibility.text: Dissemination, sharing and promotion of best accessibility practices for web content and mobile applications.
accessibility.link1: DL n.º 83/2018 - accessibility of the web and mobile applications

usability.text: Resources, tools and good practices to improve the usability and experience of using digital services.

badge.text: Seal of excellence that rewards good accessibility and usability practices on public service websites.

HOME_PAGE.header: Get an accessibility report using one of the following methods
HOME_PAGE.intro_text: Access our web accessibility practices (WCAG 2.1) assessor here. Obtain an accessibility report using one of the following methods:
HOME_PAGE.url_error: Enter a valid url. E.g. http://www.google.com
HOME_PAGE.html_label: Insert the HTML code down below

messages.invalid_url: The given url is invalid or does not exist

metadata.validator: We could not contact the W3C html markup validator
metadata.caption: Evaluated practices summary

gauge.title: AccessMonitor score. Page rating: {{value}} out of 10

results.title: Evaluation
results.subtitle: practices detected, which can be classified by:
results.caption: Evaluated practices

FOOTER.gold_badge_label: Gold Badge of Usability and Accessibility
FOOTER.img_ama: AMA – Agency for Administrative Modernization I.P.
FOOTER.img_compete_2020: COMPETE 2020 – Competitiveness and Internationalization Operational Program
FOOTER.img_european_union: European Union – European Regional Development Fund

MISC.unexpected_error: An unexpected error has ocurred. Please try again later.
MISC.error_contact: If the problem persists, please contact us.

_404.title: Error 404
_404.description: The page you tried to access does not exist.

messages.data_error: An error has ocurred while trying to retrieve user data
messages.data_table_error: An error has ocurred when trying to load the data table

ELEMS.imgAltNo: Images without equivalent alternative in text
ELEMS.aImgAltNo: Links where the only content is an image with empty alt or no caption
ELEMS.aTitleMatch: Links with the same text in content and title attribute
ELEMS.aSameText: Groups of links with the same text that point to different targets
ELEMS.aAdjacentSame: Adjacent links leading to the same destination
ELEMS.aSkipFirst: Link to skip to main content
ELEMS.aSkipFirstNo: Link that does not skip to main content
ELEMS.aSkipNo: No links to bypass content blocks
ELEMS.liNoList: List items used outside of lists
ELEMS.labelPosNo: label elements that are not visible or are incorrectly positioned.
ELEMS.inputLabelNo: Form controls without an accessible name
ELEMS.inputIdTitleNo: Form controls without associated label and without the title attribute
ELEMS.tableCaptionSummary: Tables with the same text in the caption element and the summary attribute
ELEMS.tableLayoutCaption: Tables without header cells, but with the caption element
ELEMS.tableComplexError: Complex data tables without the headers attribute in the data cells
ELEMS.newWinOnLoad: New window pops-up once the page loads
ELEMS.fontAbsVal: Font sizes defined in absolute units of measurement
ELEMS.layoutFixed: Elements with absolute values in CSS property "width"
ELEMS.valueAbsCss: Absolute units of measurement in CSS
ELEMS.valueRelCss: Relative units of measurement in CSS
ELEMS.colorContrast: Color combinations with a contrast ratio less than 4.5:1 for regular text or 3:1 for large text
ELEMS.colorFgBgNo: CSS rules in which the background color and letter color are not specified simultaneously
ELEMS.fontHtml: Elements and Attributes (X) HTML used to format the Text of pages (eg basefont, font, link, and alink)
ELEMS.layoutElemNo: No (X)HTML elements to format page layout (eg blink and center)
ELEMS.layoutElem: (X)HTML elements to format page layout (eg blink and center)
ELEMS.titleLong: Number of characters in the title element
ELEMS.titleChars: Title with non-textual string (probably ASCII art)
ELEMS.metaRefresh: meta element does not refresh the page
ELEMS.ariaStValid: Values of ARIA states and properties are of valid type
ELEMS.ariaStNotValid: Values of ARIA states and properties are invalid
ELEMS.ariaStNotPermitted: Not allowed ARIA states and properties
ELEMS.audioAvoidsAutoPlay: audio and video elementos do not play automatically
ELEMS.buttonNotAname: button does not have non-empty accessible name
ELEMS.elementDec: Elements with the aria-hidden attribute without focusable content
ELEMS.elementNotDec: Elements with the aria-hidden attribute with focusable content
ELEMS.elementNotHiddenFocus: Elements marked as decorative and exposed to assistive tecnologies
ELEMS.headerAtt: headers attributes identify cells in the same table
ELEMS.headerAttNot: headers attributes identify cells in different tables
ELEMS.iframeSameAName: iframe elements with the same accessible name present the same resource
ELEMS.iframeSameANameDiferent: iframe elements with the same accessible name
ELEMS.iframeNegTabIndex: iframe elements with negative tabindex without interactive elements
ELEMS.iframeNegTabIndexNot: iframe elements with negative tabindex with interactive elements
ELEMS.linkIdentAName: Links with the same accessible name and context
ELEMS.linkIdentANameNot: Links with the same accessible name and context but different targets
ELEMS.orientationCSSNot: Element with CSS transform property restricts the page orientation
ELEMS.scrollableAccess: Scrollable elements can be used with keyboard
ELEMS.scrollableAccessNot: Scrollable elements cannot be used with keyboard
ELEMS.svgAName: svg element with explicit semantic role and accessible name
ELEMS.svgNotAName: svg element with explicit semantic role but without accessible name
ELEMS.tableHdrNot: Table header cells without data cells
ELEMS.textContrastH: Color combinations with a contrast ratio greater than 7:1 for regular text or 4.5:1 for large text
ELEMS.textContrastHNot: Color combinations with a contrast ratio less than 7:1 for regular text or 4.5:1 for large text
ELEMS.labelANameNot: Interactive elements with visible labels that are not part of the accessible name
ELEMS.listNotCorrectly: Lists with elements that are not list items
ELEMS.descListElement: List items used within description lists
ELEMS.notDescListElement: List items used outside description lists
ELEMS.descList: Description lists with only correctly ordered list items
ELEMS.notDescList: Description lists with elements that are not list items or that are not correctly ordered

a_11.p: I found <mark>{{value}}</mark> links without accessible name

a_12.p: I noticed that <mark>all groups</mark> of links with the same accessible name and context have the same target.

a_13.p: I found <mark>{{value}}</mark> groups of links with the same accessible name and context but different targets.

menuItem_01.p: I noticed that <mark>all</mark> elements with the <code>menuitem>/code> role have an accessible name

meta_05.s: I noticed that the meta element does not prevent users from zooming.
meta_05.p: I noticed that the meta element does not prevent users from zooming.

orientation_01.p: I noticed that the orientation of the elements in this page <mark>is not</mark> restricted through CSS properties

orientation_02.p: I found <mark>{{value}}</mark> elements with CSS properties that restrict their orientation

role_02.p: I located {{value}} role attributes with invalid values

TECHS.H37: Using alt attributes on img elements
TECHS.F65: Failure of Success Criterion 1.1.1 due to omission of the alt attribute in img elements, area elements, and input elements of type "image"
TECHS.C9: Using CSS to include decorative images
TECHS.F30: Failure of Success Criteria 1.1.1 and 1.2.1 due to using text alternatives that are not alternatives (eg, file names or placeholder text)
TECHS.H24: Providing text alternatives to the area elements of image maps
TECHS.H36: Use alt attributes in images used as Submit buttons
TECHS.G125: Provide links to navigate to related Web pages
TECHS.F89: Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.4, 2.4.9 and 4.1.2 due to the use of empty alt in an image where the image is the only content in a link
TECHS.H33: Supplementing link text with the title attribute
TECHS.F84: Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.9 due to the use of a non-specific link, such as "click here" or "more" without a mechanism to change link text to specific text
TECHS.H2: Combine the adjacent image and text links for the same resource
TECHS.G1: Add a link at the top of each page to directly access the main content area
TECHS.G123: Add a link at the beginning of a block of repeated content to directly access the end of the block
TECHS.H48: Use ol, ul and dl for lists
TECHS.H71: Provide a description for groups of form controls using fieldset and legend elements
TECHS.G162: Placing labels to increase the predictability of relationships
TECHS.H44: Using label elements to associate text labels with form controls
TECHS.H65: Use the title attribute to identify form controls when the label element cannot be used
TECHS.F55: Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.1, 2.4.7 and 3.2.1 due to using script to remove focus when focus is received
TECHS.H39: Use caption elements to associate titles with data tables
TECHS.H73: Use the summary attribute of the table element to provide an overview of the data tables
TECHS.F46: Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 due to use of th elements, caption elements, or non-empty summary attributes in schema tables
TECHS.H43: Use the id and headers attributes to associate data cells with header cells in data tables
TECHS.H63: Use the scope attribute to associate header cells with data cells in data tables
TECHS.H51: Use table markup to present tabular information
TECHS.F49: Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.2 due to the use of an HTML layout table that does not make sense when linearized
TECHS.H64: Using the title attribute of the frame and the iframe elements
TECHS.F52: Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.1 due to the presentation of a new window as soon as a new page is loaded
TECHS.G102: Provide the full definition or expansion of an abbreviation
TECHS.F88: Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.8 due to the use of justified text (aligned to the left and right margins)
TECHS.C19: Specifying Left OR Right Alignment in CSS
TECHS.C24: Use percentage values in CSS for container sizes
TECHS.G145: Ensure a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1
TECHS.F24: Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.3, 1.4.6 and 1.4.8 due to specifying foreground colors without specifying background colors and vice versa
TECHS.F4: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.2 due to the use of text-decoration:blink without a mechanism to stop it in less than five seconds
TECHS.SCR20: Using the keyboard and other device-specific functions
TECHS.F59: Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.2 due to using script to make div or a span a user interface control in HTML
TECHS.C22: Use CSS to control the visual presentation of text
TECHS.G115: Use semantic elements to mark structure
TECHS.H57: Use language attributes in html element
TECHS.H25: Provide a title using the title element
TECHS.F25: Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.2 because the title of a Web page does not identify the contents
TECHS.G88: Provide descriptive titles for web pages
TECHS.H59: Use the link element and navigation tools
TECHS.F41: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.1, 2.2.4, and 3.2.5 due to the use of a meta refresh with a timeout exceeded
TECHS.F40: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.1 and 2.2.4 due to the use of a redirect goal with a time limit
TECHS.6a7281: ARIA states and properties have valid value type
TECHS.5c01ea: ARIA states and properties are allowed
TECHS.5f99a7: aria-* attributes are defined the ARIA specification
TECHS.80f0bf: Audio and video elements avoid playing automatically
TECHS.97a4e1: The accessible name of the button element is not empty
TECHS.oj04fd: Elements in sequential focus order need visible focus indicator
TECHS.6cfa84: Elements with aria-hidden have no focusable content
TECHS.46ca7f: Decorative elements are not exposed to Assistive Technologies
TECHS.H58: Using language attributes to identify changes in the human language
TECHS.307n5z: Elements with presentation children have no focusable content
TECHS.4e8ab6: Elements with role attribute have the required state and properties
TECHS.H93: Ensuring that id attributes are unique on a webpage
TECHS.4b1c6c: iframe elements with identical accessible names have equivalent purpose
TECHS.G202: svg element with explicit role has non-empty accessible name
TECHS.24afc2: Letter spacing in style attributes is not !important
TECHS.G91: Providing link text that describes the purpose of a link
TECHS.fd3a94: Links with the same accessible name and context serve the same purpose
TECHS.8fc3b6: object element rendering non-text content has non-empty accessible name
TECHS.b33eff: Orientation of the page is not restricted using CSS transform property
TECHS.d0f69e: Table header cell has assigned cells
TECHS.G17: Ensure a contrast ratio of at least 4.5 to 1
TECHS.G87: video element auditory content has accessible alternative
TECHS.G8: video element visual content has accessible alternative
TECHS.G208: Including the text of the visible label as part of the accessible name
TECHS.9e45ec: Word spacing in style attributes is not !important
TECHS.59br37: Zoomed text node is not clipped with CSS overflow
TECHS.ARIA11: Using ARIA landmarks to identify regions of a page

TXT_TECHNIQUES.H37: Check if the alternative text equivalent found in the images provides equal information or function as the one performed by the image on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F65: Check if the alternative text equivalent found in the graphic buttons serves equal information or function to the one performed by the graphic button on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C9: The use of empty alternative text in HTML is a common practice for images classified as decorative. However, all images classified as decorative should be affixed via CSS and not via HTML.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F30: In the alt attribute of the <img> element I found the image file name or one of the following values: "img", "image", "spacer", "space", "picture ", "alt", "alttext", "imagen", "imagem", "foto", "photo", or one of the following image file extensions .jpg, .jpeg, .gif, .png. None of the elements referred above serves as an alternative textual equivalent.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H45: The longdesc attribute must be composed by an URL that points the location where the long description can be found - it can point to other page or ta bookmark in the same page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H24: Check if the alternative text equivalent that exists in the active areas in the image maps serves information ou has an equal function to the one performed by the image map on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H36: The <input> element is used to create many types of form controls. Despite of the DTD of HTML and XHTML allowing the use of the alt attribute in all its elements, the alt attribute should be used, in case of the <input> element, only when it represents a graphical button.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G125: The WWW nature is to provide links on webpages to other related webpages. This is what allows users to navigate to information. One webpage without links is strange, at first sight!
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F89: This fail occurs when a link is composed by an image and that image has an empty alternative textual equivalent - I suspect that users of Assistive Technology don't know the link’s destination or purpose, or may even don't realize the existence of the link.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H33: The title attribute is used to provide additional information to that one existent in the link’s text. The attribute title and the text of the link should be sufficient to understand the link purpose.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F84: It is important that users are able to determine the link's purpose and target without the need to examine the context where it is located. There are Assistive Technologies that provide their users with a list of all the webpage's links, without any further context.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H2: When adjacent links point to exactly the same resource, we can put them together in just one link. Usually, in these situations, we have the visual sensation of having one single link but some Assistive Technologies render two links, what can be confusing.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G1: Make available, at the top of the webpage, a link that allows skipping directly to the main content of the webpage. This link facilitates the navigation for many users, namely those who use scanning selection software. These users use vision to read information so the links must be always visible ou become visible when receiving the focus.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G123: Check if the links that I found provide the most suitable way to skip to the content; if  they are  always visible or if become visible when receiving focus by keyboard.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H42: Web pages must be marked with a hierarchical structure of headings and subheadings. Each page should have, at least, one level 1 heading. The level 2 should mark the sections and the level 3 the subsections. This same logic must be applied until the level 6 subsections.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G141: The web pages must be marked with a hierarchical structure of headings and subheadings. Each page should have, at least, one level 1 heading. The level 2 should mark the sections and the level 3 the subsections of these. This same logic must be applied until the subsections of level 6.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G130: Headings must be descriptive but at the same time brief. Its content, in any situation, should never be empty - it is what's happening in this case.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H48: If the content that I identified is, in fact, a list of options then use the correct structural marking (i.e. <ul>, <ol>).
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H71: Form controls can be grouped, according to their purpose, through the <fieldset> element. The first element inside a <fieldset> should be a <legend>, which acts as a label or description for the grouping.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G162: Labels should be positioned just before the fields. Labels for checkbox fields or radio button fields should be positioned just after the fields.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H44: <label> elements associated with <input> elements allow Assistive Technology users to identify the label that contextualizes an edit field. The explicit association is done by the pair id and for attributes, respectively, in the <input> and <label> elements.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H65: To fill edit fields, users need those to be identified. It can be an explicit identification (marked in the code) or implicit (usually derived from the relative position). Explicitly it can be done with the <label> element or the title attribute of the <input> element.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F55: Navigate the edit fields and check if the focus is inhibited through programmatic techniques. When removing focus, the content becomes no longer operable by those who use only keyboard to navigate.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H32: After filling a form, it is necessary to submit the data to the server. This is the function of the submit button.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H39: I suspect that I might have found data tables without the title identification provided by the <caption> element.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H73: I suspect that I might have found data tables with the same content in the <caption> element and the summary attribute.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F46: I suspect that I might have found data tables which are missing headers. Otherwise, they could be layout tables and in this case have a title, which you must remove.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H43: In complex data tables (with headings in various rows) it is important to associate explicitly the data cells to the various headings which contextualize them. That association is done with the headers attribute.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H63: The scope attribute identifies if a cell constitutes a heading of a line, of a column, of a group of lines or of a group of columns. The values row, col, rowgroup and colgroup identify respectively the values that the scope may assume.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H51: Despite WCAG not prohibiting the use of layout tables it is recommended not to use them. If the tables used contain data then mark the heading cells conveniently.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F49: After the tables have been linearized, check if the content is perceptible.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H64: Frames are windows where it is possible to see content coming from another server. It is important to conveniently identify those frames. Use the title attribute for that purpose!
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F52: Some Web sites open a new window when a page is loaded, to advertise a product or service. Make sure this does not disorient users.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G102: Mark the abbreviations and/or acronyms with the respective expansion. In the HTML5 is used the <abbr> element to mark abbreviations or acronyms. For instance: <abbr title="Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia">FCT</abbr>
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C21: Many people with cognitive disabilities have difficulty to follow the text lines when the text has a simple spacing. Using a spacing between 1,5 and 2 will help them when skipping lines.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F88: Some persons with low vision and persons with cognitive impairments have difficulties in dealing with justified text blocks.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C19: Some persons with low vision and persons with cognitive impairments have difficulties in dealing with justified text blocks.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C12: When the text size is expressed in absolute units some browsers will have difficulty zooming text.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G146: Zoom the screen 200% and check that all the content is visible without the need to scroll horizontally.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C24: Zoom the screen 200% and check that all the content is visible without the need to scroll horizontally.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G145: According to success criteria 1.4.3, a 3 to 1 ratio is the minimum ratio for text "in large size" (18pt or 14 pt bold, or larger). I warn that for normal font size the minimum ratio is 4,5 to 1.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F24: It is not required that the font colour and the background colour be defined in the same CSS rule but it is recommended. This is the only way to ensure that the user is presented with the desired contrast.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F4: Some user groups, particularly those who have attention deficit disorders, find blinking content to be distractive, making it difficult to concentrate in other parts of the webpage.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G90: You must ensure that javascript events are activated not only by mouse but also by keyboard. Check the pairs of event handlers: mousedown/keydown, mouseup/keyup, mouseover/focus, mouseout/blur. Note: AccessMonitor does not check the pair onclick / onkeypress because it considers that browsers also support the onclick event when using the keyboard. This test is correctly classified only when there aren't errors in the other tests of handlers.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.SCR20: You must ensure that javascript events are activated not only by mouse but also by keyboard. Check the pairs of event handlers: mousedown/keydown, mouseup/keyup, mouseover/focus, mouseout/blur. Note: AccessMonitor does not check the pair onclick / onkeypress because it considers that browsers also support the onclick event when using the keyboard.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F59: Generic elements, such as <div> and <span>, do not have a predefined role. When using these generic elements to create user interface controls in HTML, Assistive Technologies do not have enough information to describe and interact with the controls, namely if no "role" has been defined with ARIA techniques.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G134: HTML errors are one of the causes of webpages being presented in an inconsistent way in different browsers. To follow the specification and to validate the syntax according to that specification enhances the consistency and the correct interpretation, namely by Assistive Technologies.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C22: This practice is obsolete. Instead, you should use CSS to control the visual presentation of text. When this error occurs you are using inside the <body> element of the webpage, one of the elements: b, basefont, font, i, s, strike, u, or the attributes: text, vlink, alink, link.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G115: With the appearance of CSS, all the HTML elements used to control styles of the webpage became obsolete. Elements such as: b, big, blink, center, font, i, s, strike, u became obsolete - use CSS to replace them.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H57: HTML only uses the lang attribute. XHTML 1.1 only uses the xml:lang attribute. XHTML 1.0 (as a transitional measure) allows both attributes. XHTML served as text/html uses the lang and xml:lang attributes on the html element.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H25: Take note that the <title> element should only appear once in the webpage.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F25: It is defined as a failure condition a webpage having a title equal to the title of another webpage of the same website. Each page should have a unique title which identifies the purpose of its content.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G88: The <title> of each webpage should: (1) identify the page's subject; (2) make sense when read out of context; (3) be short.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H59: Check if in each of the <link> elements that exist in the <head> of the webpage, the href points to an adequate resource.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F41: The value "refresh" should be used carefully, as it takes control away from the user.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F40: The value “redirect" should be used carefully, as it takes control away from the user.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.ff89c9: Anytime the semantic role of an element is explicitly defined, you need to ensure that, whenever the role has a required context, the element’s parent nodes provide that context.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.bc4a75: Anytime the semantic role of an element is explicitly defined, you need to ensure that, whenever the role has required children, the element’s is parent to at least one of the required elements.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.6a7281: The ARIA specification defines the valid type of values for the ARIA states and properties. Make sure you use valid value types, otherwise your code will not work as intended.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.5c01ea: The HTML and ARIA specifications define the ARIA states and properties that are allowed for the different HTML elements. Make sure you use allowed states and properties, otherwise your code will not work as intended.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.5f99a7: The ARIA specification defines the set of attributes that can be used. If you use attributes that are not defined by the specification, they will not work.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.80f0bf: <audio> and <video> elements that play automatically can prevent screen reader users from listening the screen reader output clearly. Consequently, these elements should not play automatically, or, in case they do, the audio should last less than 3 seconds or they should make available a mechanism to stop or mute the audio.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.73f2c2: The rules for autocomplete attributes are defined in the HTML specification. Make sure you follow the specification, otherwise the elements will not be automatically filled.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.97a4e1: <button&t; elements are elements that the user can interact with. Consequently, they must have an accessible name that allows users of Assistive Technology to understand their purpose.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.oj04fd: A visible focus allows distinguishing when elements in the sequential focus order receive focus. Check that all elements in the sequential focus order have a visible focus indicator when they receive focus.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.6cfa84: Elements with the aria-hidden attribute are hidden from Assistive Technologies. If they are keyboard focusable, users of Assistive Technologies will receive no feedback when those elements are focused.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.46ca7f: Decorative elements have no informational content to be presented to users. Therefore, these elements should not be exposed to Assistive Technologies, preventing them from being presented to users of Assistive Technologies.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H58: Changes in the language of a document should be identified through the usage of the lang attribute.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.307n5z: Elements with a semantic role that makes their children presentational should not have focusable content, otherwise, when the content receives focus it will not be presented to users of Assistive Technologies.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.4e8ab6: Anytime the semantic role of an element is explicitly defined, you must ensure that all states and properties required by that semantic role have been specified, otherwise the element will not work with Assistive Technologies as expected.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H93: Problems for assistive technologies are known to be caused when different elements have the same id attribute. These problems can be avoided by making sure that a webpage does not have duplicate id values.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.4b1c6c: The accessible name of an iframe element is what allows users of Assistive Technologies to understand the element’s purpose. Make sure that when two iframe elements have the same accessible name, they also have the same purpose.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G202: Check if the alternative text equivalent found in the svg elements provides equal information or function as the one performed by the image on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.24afc2: A letter spacing equal to or larger than 0.12 times the font size is important to ensure that all users are able to read the text. CSS styles should not prevent users from increasing the letter spacing if they so desire.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G91: A link’s description lets a user understand where it leads and whether to follow the link or not.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.fd3a94: It is important that links with the same accessible name that share the same context, do not link to targets with different purposes, otherwise users will not be able to understand where the link leads them to.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.m6b1q3: Elements with the menutiem role represent navigation options which the user can interact with. If they do not have an accessible name, users of Assistive Technology will not to be able to understand the option they are selecting.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G110: Client-side redirects that do not happen instantaneously might confuse users, because they will not understand what cause the redirect to happen.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.b4f0c3: Some older mobile browsers may limit a user’s ability to zoom on the page, depending on the value of the attribute viewport of the element meta. Even though modern browsers ignore these attributes, it is always best to not instruct the browser in a way that can limit a user’s abilities.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.8fc3b6: Whenever an object element renders non-text content it is important to ensure that it has an accessible name, otherwise users of Assistive Technologies will not be able to know what content is being presented by the object element.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.b33eff: Some users must use their devices in a specific orientation. If a page prevents its content to adjust to the device’s orientation, those users will not be blocked from using the page as it is intended.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.674b10: To able to correctly convey content and interaction possibilities, Assistive Technologies need to understand the semantic of elements within a page. When you explicitly define the role of an element, make sure that the value of the role is a valid one.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.d0f69e: In data tables, the table cells are interpreted based on the information conveyed through the headers (both row and column headers). The headers must be, implicitly or explicitly, assigned to data cells.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G17: According to success criteria 1.4.6, a 4.5 to 1 ratio is the otimized ratio for text "in large size" (18pt or 14 pt bold, or larger). I recall that for normal font size the otmized ratio is 7 to 1.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G87: An accessible alternative to the audio content of a video should be presented on the page. The alternative can be captions on the video or the inclusion of text conveying the same information as the audio on the video.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G8: An accessible alternative to the visual content of a video should be available on the page. The alternative can be the audio description or a transcript of the video.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G208: Speech input users typically say the name of a command followed by a reference to the text of an element (e.g., click search to active the button labelled “search”). Speech input systems use the element’s accessible name to match the element to the command. Therefore, if the element’s accessible name does not incude visible text label, it will not be possible to associate the element with the command.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.9e45ec: A word spacing equal to or larger than 0.16 times the font size is important to ensure that all users are able to read the text. CSS styles should not prevent users from increasing the word spacing if they so desire.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.59br37: When zooming on a page, the relative size of text and respective container might change, resulting in extra space being needed to present the same text. The CSS property overflow determines how the containers adjust when zooming. Some of its values might result in text clipping.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.ARIA11: Ensure that there is only one main landmark in the page. Main landmarks designate the main content of the page and make it easy for screen reader users to quickly navigate to it. Each page should only have one main content, irrespectively of it being designated using HTML5 or ARIA.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H40:
If description lists contain non list item elements, or if the order of the list item elements is not appropriate, that is,

elements should precede
elements, the list will be incorrectly marked up, and assistive technologies will not be able to render it correctly.

TECHFAIL.relationT: This WCAG 2.1 technique is related to:
